change.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to become different, or to make something become different
change.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Susan has changed a lot since I last saw her.
Changing your eating habits is the best way to lose weight.
The leaves on trees change colour in the autumn.
He changed from being a nice lad to being rude and unhelpful.
The hissing sound gradually changed into a low hum.
A witch had changed him into a mouse.
Mueller changed his name to Miller when he became a U.S. citizen.
change.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to stop doing or using one thing, and start doing or using something else instead
change.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The ship changed course and headed south.
The company has had to change direction because of developments in technology.
Piper awkwardly tried to change the subject (=talk about something else).
The company has recently changed to a more powerful computer system.
change.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to put or use something new or different in place of something else, especially because it is old, damaged, or broken
change.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Three boys were changing a tyre by the side of the road.
When I lost my keys, we had to change all the locks.
How often do you change cars  (=buy a new car and sell the old one)?
The time of the meeting has been changed from 11:00 to 10:30.
change.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to take off your clothes and put on different ones
change.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Francis came in while Jay was changing.
Change your dress – that one looks dirty.
You’d better go and get changed.
Sara changed into her swimsuit and ran out for a quick swim.
change.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to put a clean nappy on a baby, or to put clean clothes on a baby or small child
change.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: I bathed him and changed his diaper.
change.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to take the dirty sheets off a bed and put on clean ones
change.translation[0].definitions[6].def: to take back to a shop something that you have bought and get something different instead, especially because there is something wrong with it
change.translation[0].definitions[6].exa: I bought these gloves for my daughter, but they’re too large. Can I change them for a smaller size?
change.translation[0].definitions[7].def: to give a customer something different instead of what they have bought, especially because there is something wrong with it
change.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: I’m sure the shop will change them for you.
change.translation[0].definitions[8].def: to get smaller units of money that add up to the same value as a larger unit
change.translation[0].definitions[9].def: to get money from one country for the same value of money from another country
change.translation[0].definitions[9].exa: I want to change my dollars into pesos, please.
change.translation[0].definitions[10].de: to get off one train, bus, or aircraft and onto another in order to continue your journey
change.translation[0].definitions[10].no: all change! (=used to tell passengers to get off a train because it does not go any further)
change.translation[0].definitions[10].ex: I had to change planes in Denver.
Passengers for Liverpool should change at Crewe.
change.translation[0].definitions[11].de: to put the engine of a vehicle into a higher or lower gear in order to go faster or slower
change.translation[0].definitions[11].ex: Change into second gear as you approach the corner.
Change down before you get to the hill.
change.translation[0].definitions[12].de: if the wind changes, it starts to blow in a different direction
change.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: People’s work environment has changed dramatically in the past twenty years.
His life had completely changed since he met Anya.
He has changed considerably in four years.
The legal system has changed significantly since the rule was established.
The political situation has fundamentally changed.
The market for phones is changing rapidly.
Old habits cannot be changed overnight.
The human brain adapts quickly to changing conditions.
Changing attitudes cause traditional ways of life to disappear.
the changing role of women in society
Changing patterns of work mean that more people are able to work from home.
In order to survive, you must adapt to a changing environment.
Children are growing up in a changing world.
change.translation[0].note_box[1].items[: Change belongs to a group of verbs where the same noun can be the subject of the verb or its object
In this sentence, ‘the password’ is the object of change
In this sentence, ‘the password’ is the subject of change
change.translation[0].note_box[2].sectio: to change something
to make someone or something different
Unfortunately, there’s nothing we can do to change the situation.
Being at college has changed her – she’s much more confident now.
alter
to change something so that it is better or more suitable
You can alter the colour and size of the image using a remote control.
Can we alter the date of the meeting?
adapt
to change something slightly in order to improve it or make it more suitable
How much would it cost to adapt the existing equipment?
You can adapt the recipe to suit your own requirements.
adjust
to make small changes in the position or level of something in order to improve it or make it more suitable
How do you adjust the volume on the television?
He adjusted his tie in the mirror.
modify
to make small changes to something such as a piece of equipment, a set of ideas, or a way of behaving in order to improve it or use it in a different way
He’s modified his opinions since then.
a modified version of the original program
reform
to change a law, system, organization etc so that it is fairer or more effective
plans to reform the tax system
Health care needs to be completely reformed.
revise
to change a plan, idea, law etc because of new information and ideas
In July, China revised the rules for foreign investment.
The findings could force the scientists to revise their ideas about climate change.
reorganize
to change the way that a system or organization works
We’ve had to reorganize our database.
During the 1980s, the government reorganized the civil service.
restructure
to make big changes to the way something is organized, especially a large political or economic system or a big company, in order to make it more effective
The company has been restructured from top to bottom.
to change something completely
transform
to change something completely, especially so that it is much better
Well, you’ve certainly transformed this place – it looks great!
Putin transformed the Russian economy.
revolutionize
to completely and permanently change the way people do something or think about something, especially because of a new idea or invention
Computers have revolutionized the way we work.
This important discovery revolutionized our understanding of the universe.
to change something in order to deceive people
distort
to explain facts, statements etc in a way that makes them seem different from what they really are
The judge said that she had deliberately tried to distort the facts.
Don’t try to distort the truth.
twist
to dishonestly change the meaning of a piece of information or of something that someone has said, in order to get an advantage for yourself or to support your own opinion
He accused reporters of twisting his words.
In her article she twisted the meaning of what I said.
misrepresent
to give people a wrong idea about someone or their opinions, by what you write or say
I hope I have not misrepresented her opinion.
He’s taking legal action to stop the film, claiming it grossly misrepresents him.
change.translation[1].definitions[0].def: the process or result of something or someone becoming different
change.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: I find it hard to cope with change.
No major changes were made to the book.
She had a change of heart (=change in attitude) and decided to stay.
Family life has undergone dramatic change in recent years.
There was a change for the better in the patient’s condition.
the sweeping political changes after the fall of communism
A change in personality may mean your teenager has a drug problem.
change.translation[1].definitions[1].def: the fact of one thing or person being replaced by another
change.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The car needs an oil change.
The government has made some major policy changes.
the gradual change from grasslands to true desert
change.translation[1].definitions[2].def: a situation or experience that is different from what happened before, and is usually interesting or enjoyable
change.translation[1].definitions[2].not: a change is as good as a rest (=used to say that starting to do something different is as good as having a rest)
change.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: ‘Ron’s buying the drinks.’ ‘That makes a change.’
The patients benefit greatly from a change of scenery.
The morning was cool; a welcome change from the heat of the day before.
How about dinner out for a change?
change.translation[1].definitions[3].def: the money that you get back when you have paid for something with more money than it costs
change.translation[1].definitions[4].def: money in the form of coins, not paper money
change.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: Matt emptied the loose change from his pockets.
A beggar asked for some spare change (=coins that you do not need).
I have about a dollar in change.
change.translation[1].definitions[5].def: coins or paper money that you give in exchange for the same amount of money in a larger unit
change.translation[1].definitions[5].exa: Excuse me, have you got change for a pound?
change.translation[1].definitions[6].def: a situation in which you get off one train, bus, or aircraft and get on another in order to continue your journey
change.translation[1].definitions[6].exa: Even with a change of trains, the subway is quicker than a cab at rush hour.
change.translation[1].note_box[0].sectio: big/major
Going to a new school is a big change for children.
slight/small/minor
The proposed changes were relatively minor.
gradual
There has been a gradual change in the weather.
dramatic/drastic/radical
The Industrial Revolution was a period of dramatic change.
The change in blood pressure was not significant.
marked
There was a marked change in his behaviour.
fundamental
Reducing waste requires a fundamental change in attitude.
social/political/economic etc change
Demands for political and social change are growing.
sweeping changes
There are likely to be sweeping changes in the company.
far-reaching changes
The Internet has brought about far-reaching changes in the way we work.
make a change
We've had to make some changes to the design.
introduce a change
A number of changes were introduced to the curriculum.
bring (about) change
The war brought about radical social change.
Treatment is aimed at effecting a change in the child’s negative behaviour.
see/notice/observe a change
I saw a big change in her when I met her again.
undergo a change
The body undergoes a number of changes during this time.
signal a change
Does this move signal a change in US foreign policy?
the pace/rate of change
People sometimes feel alarmed by the pace of technological change.
change.translation[1].note_box[1].sectio: a situation in which someone or something becomes different, or the act of making something different
There was a sudden change in the weather.
We are living in a period of great change.
He was told to make some slight changes to his essay.
alteration
a change, especially a small one that happens naturally or gradually, or one that is made in order to improve something
I noticed a slight alteration in her behaviour.
They had to make some alterations to their original theory.
reform
a change made to a system or law in order to improve it
He called for a reform of our outdated voting system.
Many people opposed the economic reforms.
shift
a change, especially in people’s attitudes or in the way they do things, or in the position of someone or something
a shift in public opinion about the war
There has been a noticeable shift in government policy on education.
There needs to be a major shift away from road transport to rail transport.
After he died, there was a dramatic shift in the balance of power.
swing
a big change, especially in someone’s opinions or moods
There has been a big swing toward the Democrats  (=many more people are supporting them).
The drug can cause mood swings.
fluctuation
a change in something – used when something changes often
fluctuations in the value of the dollar
temperature fluctuations
fluctuations in his mood
There has been some fluctuation in productivity levels.
a great change
transformation
a change in which something or someone becomes completely different
There has been a complete transformation in his attitude since he became a father.
her transformation from shy local girl to famous movie actress
revolution
a complete change in ways of thinking or working
The 1970s saw the beginnings of a new technological revolution.
Einstein’s General Theory of Relativity started a revolution in scientific thinking.
shake-up
a situation in which a lot of changes are very quickly made in a system or organization in order to make it more effective
The department has not performed well and is badly in need of a shake-up.
The Administration is planning a thorough shake-up of the welfare system.
U-turn
a complete change in the plans of a government or political party so that it decides to do the opposite of what it originally said it would do
The government was forced to do a U-turn after angry protests about their taxation policy.
change.translation[2].definitions[0].def: to exchange a unit of money for smaller units that add up to the same value
change.translation[2].definitions[1].def: to exchange money in one currency into money of another currency
change.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: I want to change these dollars into Euros.
change.translation[2].definitions[2].def: to exchange something that you have bought, especially because there is something wrong with it
change.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: We will only change goods accompanied by a receipt.
change.translation[2].definitions[3].def: if property changes hands, it passes from one owner to another
change.translation[2].definitions[3].exa: Volume was heavy on the NYSE, where about 2.19 billion shares changed hands.
change.translation[3].definitions[0].def: the money you get back when you have paid for something with more money than it costs
change.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: She received a forged banknote in her change.
You won’t get much change from a ten pound note here.
change.translation[3].definitions[1].def: money in the form of coins and notes of low value
change.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: I have about a dollar in change.
I didn’t have any small change for the telephone.
